Message.Title: How Romney plans to pay for his tax cut for the RICH
Message.Msg: Obama took $712 billion out of Medicare to pay for Obamacare. Romneyhood plans to use the $712 billion (after he kills Obamacare) to fund his tax cut plan which ,as Obama says, greatly favors the rich. So, Romney/Ryan want to use Medicare as a piggy bank too. At least under Obamanomics, somebody besides rich people get something for what they're stealing off of seniors. Both Obama or Romney want to use more medicare money for their stimulus programs and tax breaks, but, Obama wants to trash the rich fat cats at the same time. Romney, on the other hand, plans to trash Medicade, welfare, food stanps and student loans to balance the budget. Romney also wants to "broaden" the tax base, meaning reduce deductions which force more low income people into paying more taxes. Subtract the earned income tax credit, a Romney proposal, and poor W2 workers who used to get $400 will get $0. Capping the total deductions at $19,000 under Romney, forces millions of middle class families into paying Federal taxes who, because of their exemptions, paid no Federal tax. So, the millionaire and billionaire marginal rate on earned income goes from 35% to 25%, but, the lower middle class get to fund that tax break along with the seniors. Under Romney/Ryan nothing will change for current seniors, yea, right. He forgot to mention that increases in medicare will be limited to GDP growth + .5%, or 1.8% based on Q3 GDP. So, where does the difference between the 10% growh in medical costs and the 1.8% cap on Medicare come from? Yea, you guessed it, THE SENIORS. Obama, on the other hand, will take the increased cost out of the doctors and hospitals, who in turn, will take it out of Medicare patients. Face it seniors, you're getting it up the #$%$ by both partys.

Topic.Title: Reminds Me of People on this Board

Message.Msg: "If you piled up all the Demorats and Republicans exhibiting this behavior, the piles would be about equal." This is a real REPUBLICAN TOE TAPPER: Scott DesJarlais, Pro-Life Republican Congressman And Doctor, Pressured Mistress Patient To Get Abortion Posted: 10/10/2012 10:13 am EDT Huffington Post WASHINGTON -- A pro-life, family-values congressman who worked as a doctor before winning election as a Tea Party-backed Republican had an affair with a patient and later pressured her to get an abortion, according to a phone call transcript obtained by The Huffington Post. The congressman, Rep. Scott DesJarlais of Tennessee, was trying to save his marriage at the time, according to his remarks on the call, made in September of 2000. And, according to three independent sources familiar with the call and the recording, he made the tape himself. DesJarlais, who was provided a copy of the transcript by HuffPost, did not deny its contents, but in a statement released through his campaign characterized it as just another sordid detail dredged up by the opposition. "Desperate personal attacks do not solve our nation's problems, yet it appears my opponents are choosing to once again engage in the same gutter politics that CBS news called the dirtiest in the nation just 2 years ago."

Topic.Title: Marsavian please do this board a favor and keep debunking Wallisweaver

Message.Msg: I don't think it's really important to decide whether design or fabrication will be the most important factor in Intel's success, but it has been a waste of time to discuss design, what with all the fanbois and quite a few others who considered ARM micro-architecture to be the greatest thing since sliced bread. I will happily leave that argument for you to make. Otellini himself felt that fabrication would be the distinguishing factor in the competition with ARM so at least I have one person on my side of the argument. Intel's tick-tock strategy is effective. While I rarely commented on the design side I never denigrated its importance to Intel's overall performance. My primary comment was that ARM's design would not be strong enough to preclude the need for them to keep pace with fabrication. I stand by that statement. I agree that it is not necessary to make things up, but just because the story itself is good enough doesn't mean the Wall Street cretins or the shills on this board will understand it or stop subverting it. Recent action is evidence enough of this. Given Wall Street's continuous effort to trap Intel in a trading range, I believe it is necessary for some of us to present the very many positives. If I err in this I'm sure you will correct me. I also may have confused you with the blackandblueredmonk. I can see why this might be considered horribly offensive. My apologies. At least I didn't confuse you with Lucy even when Lucy was pretending to be Vinnie Bag O Donuts, fixing computers in his garage and connecting iPads to corporate mainframes. What a joke. Well, Lucy is too busy expressing his incurable angst over getting fired from Intel. He is in too much emotional, whiny pain to discuss design or fabrication. I hope you survive the beatings you will get for appearing to agree with any of my statements or conclusions. If the Wall Street analysts weren't such a bunch of wimps they would prolly come over to your house. Saying Intel will reach $50 is considered blasphemy on Wall Street, you know...

Topic.Title: Marsavian please do this board a favor and keep debunking Wallisweaver

Message.Msg: I think we are in broad agreement Wallis with perhaps one exception 'My primary comment was that ARM's design would not be strong enough to preclude the need for them to keep pace with fabrication. I stand by that statement.' I have a feeling that Apple's A6 processor maybe the current exception to that rule of thumb as it is quite a tour de force (similar performance/clock to Intel's first mobile chip, Banias/Dothan aka Pentium-M) but here's the deal it doesn't really matter if it is because Apple products are a closed proprietary system which is why Wintel PCs took off in the first place and not Macs. Intel is truly competing against ARM on Windows 8 and Android and I have no doubt Silvermont will clean A15/S4's clocks in that regard. Intel doesn't need to beat Apple just the other half of the market and any success in that regard will send bright neon lights to the market that Intel is not a PC dinosaur but a continual maker of the world's best chips in whatever devices they are designed to go. Once that Eureka moment dawns on both the market and the dumb AnaLysts then INTC will start appreciating to its true valuation which is around $40-50. Until then for longs it will just be a question of trying to time the bottom for further accumulation. On a further note about phone chips Medfield is like the advance front special forces soldier making the initial foray on ARM territory but the shortly upcoming dual-core dual-gpu LTE Z2580 is the chip that will be heavy duty enough to mix it up successfully with the multi-core ARM chips on all cpu/gpu performance benchmarks/specifications and not just javascript. But just as important as that is CloverTrail. It is a truly unique product, a fully functional full legacy touch-enabled Windows PC in a truly mobile iPad format. It should really sell well to enterprises and more than make up for the death of the netbook and is truly the right product at the right time for 2013. Finally it is an Intel mobile invasion like you claimed but we are only at the storming of the beach front stage but the end result I suspect will be like D-Day in the end ;-).

Topic.Title: Marsavian please do this board a favor and keep debunking Wallisweaver

Message.Msg: 'The A15 will have a higher IPC than the A6' I don't believe it will but we shall both have to wait and see on that score ;-). ----- Indeed:) Yes, the Razr I has got great battery life, but lets see what it's like when it's got a decent GPU and LTE:) Apple A6 Includes Custom CPU October 8, 2012 Author: Linley Gwennap At the iPhone 5 announcement, Apple did not disclose what CPU it used in its new A6 application processor. Recent information, however, indicates that it designed its own CPU rather than licensing a Cortex-A9 or next-generation Cortex-A15 from ARM. Rumors about Apple working on a CPU design have swirled for years, but the company had never publicly confirmed them. Initial analysis of shipping iPhone 5 units, however, confirms that the A6 uses a unique ARM-compatible CPU design that has never been seen before. The new processor is a dual-core design, eschewing the trendy quad-core approach used in high-end smartphones from Samsung and others. Except on the relatively small number of apps that can effectively use four CPUs, the A6 will easily outperform any quad-core Cortex-A9 processor. While competitors push their CPUs to 1.5GHz and beyond, the iPhone 5 clocks the new processor at 1.3GHz, although we expect the chip to achieve faster speeds in a future iPad. Benchmark testing confirms Apple’s claims that the new CPU delivers twice the performance of the Apple A5 processor in the iPhone 4S. Apple also beefed up the GPU, giving the A6 twice the graphics performance of the A5 and roughly the same as the massive A5X. Yet the A6 chip measures 95mm2, making it 22% smaller than the original A5. Die analysis by UBM TechInsights confirms that the A6 processor is manufactured in Samsung’s 32nm HKMG technology, a full generation improvement from the 45nm technology that Samsung used to build the original A5. Samsung also uses the 32nm process to build a shrink version of the A5, which is currently shipping in a revised iPad 2, in the third-generation Apple TV, and in the newest iPod Touch, so the technology is well proven. Despite the global legal battle between Apple and Samsung over smartphone design, the companies continue to work together on Apple’s processors. The 2x gain in CPU performance implies that the A6 CPU executes 20% more instructions per cycle (IPC) than the Cortex-A9 CPU in the A5 processor. Both Cortex-A15 and Krait are rated at about 30% more IPC than Cortex-A9, putting the A6 CPU in or near the same performance class. Although some comparisons show the 1.3GHz iPhone 5 outperforming smartphones using 1.5GHz Krait processors, we believe these apples-to-oranges results are influenced by the greater memory bandwidth of the A6 and the better performance of iOS versus Android.

Topic.Title: Actually up 5 cents in the pre-market, will it hold?

Message.Msg: When a big shop recommends buying a Bear Put Spread, it will put negative pressure on the stock. They will be buying the high strike put options near $22 strike and selling the lower strike put options near $19 strike for some DEBIT price. When the INTC stock price goes up, the price of the put spread DEBIT goes down and the option market maker starts executing the orders. He will be trying to place as many of the put options as possible but those that he holds will have to be hedged. How will he neutralize the possibility/likelihood that he will get $22 shares back? He will be shorting a percentage of shares to lower his risk and lock profits. There is a good chance that Intel will not likely trade above $22 until after next Tuesday earnings. It will take some effort and good news to change the negative senitment that weigh it down. Watch option volumes for next Friday 10/20 for earnings plays and Nov expiration for dividend hedging.

Topic.Title: Actually up 5 cents in the pre-market, will it hold?

Message.Msg: The option market maker makes markets for options. He has to provide a BID and ASK price for options across various strikes and expirations. If someone offers to WRITE/SELL an option at the BID price and he cannot find a HOLDER/BUYER for the option, he becomes the HOLDER/BUYER. If someone offers to BUY/HOLD an option at the ASK price and he cannot find a WRITER/SELLER for the option, he becomes the WRITER/SELLER. He wants risk to be near or at zero and will blend a mix of PUT options, CALL options and EQUITY positions. Good reading topics: SYNTHETIC OPTION POSITIONS PUT SELLING CONSERVATIVE BUYING SIMPLE CASE: Say he has to SELL/WRITE some $25 NOV PUT options. He gets about a $3.50 premium for selling the put but will likely be faced with having to buy shares at $25 in NOV. How does he neutralize his risk to zero. He will short the shares of Intel so when he has to buy the shares for $25 in 37 days, he will not lose any money on the down side. If he has to buy shares in 37 days at $25 and he has $3.50 premium from the PUT BUYER, his effective cost is $21.50. With Intel trading at $21.85, the option market maker locks in a 35 cent profit ($21.85 - $21.50 = $0.35) by shorting Intel. If someone buys 10,000 $25 NOV INTC PUT contracts, they will cause the option market maker to short shares as long as the option market maker can cover the order and still make a profit. If the share price moves down, he stops shorting. If Intel moves up, he shorts. This is why you see INTC trade in a VERY NARROW price range. It gets MUCH, MUCH more complex and it is very hard to figure out option combination orders where multiple options are linked.

Message.Msg: The analysts believe the "PC is dead" and that Intel is a PC company. The analysts believe that ARM will make a significant impact on the Intel ASP, profit margin and may take significant market share. Especially IF Apple converts its MAC lines to ARM (Note to Wallis .... I said this is what I think is influencing ANALYSTS and I am not saying it is true or false) . The analysts believe that Intel cannot be successful in the new product market and compete with the low priced ARM based products. SInce Intel has a VERY large percentage of the PC and SERVER computing market, there is more risk in them losing share than gaining (since their share is at 90%). The analysts do not believe that Intel knows what is going on. Intel has warned on earnings twice in the last 4 quarters. Once for a flood that wiped out an overly concentrated disk drive operation in Thailand and the second time this quarter after Intel customers changed their orders. I doubt that Intel would have warned before their customers. Laptop, desktop and server CPU chips are still a dominant part of their revenue.

Topic.Title: Marsavian please do this board a favor and keep debunking Wallisweaver

Message.Msg: You chide people for not knowing basic stuff when your own failure to understanding the common principles of accounting comes shining through. Intel's superior fabrication and manufacturing will allow them to set prices that produce a profit. Because of the volumes you don't really need much of an individual item profit. If ARM can make a profit in mobility so can Intel. Intel is the only company whose fabrication prowess allows them to control the economics at 14, 10 and 7nm and to continuously reduce costs. ARM is at the situation where it no longer can count on lower unit prices at those die sizes. Basic stuff like this goes over peoples heads. ----- When you talk about ARM (in the above context), you actually mean ARM's customers, Nvida, QCOM and the rest. ARM (the company) earns royalty on shipping cores (typically 1 to 2%) on the billions it ships every quarter. Intel is on a completely different scale. As for the accounting principles of principles, I understand them well, by the look of things, better than you. You clearly don't know that the foundries (historically at least) pump out silicon cheaper than Intel can. A fact admitted by Intel when it signed the deal with TSMC for Atom IP a couple of years back. There is a reason why Intel hasn't moved it's basebands from TSMC to it's own process tech. Currently Intel's (atom) CPU cores are significantly larger than the ARM CPU's, resulting in larger chips (Cloverview is 15% larger than Tegra 3 even with a process advantage - yes, Cloverview should also be faster, at least on paper). However, there is some truth to your argument. It only holds if Intel can far enough ahead of the foundries in (low power) node terms...

Topic.Title: Marsavian please do this board a favor and keep debunking Wallisweaver

Message.Msg: 'Intel's superior fabrication and manufacturing will allow them to set prices that produce a profit.' This is the true strength of fabrication advantage, it allows you to be the last man left standing in any price war. Having your own Fabs also helps to accentuate this price advantage. Any ARM vendors who currently don't have volume are dead men walking when they are faced in 2013 by premium x86 mobile chips on the n process and cheap but still fast x86 mobile chips on the n-1 process e.g. 22nm Silvermont and 32nm Medfield. East wanted an ARMs race with Intel, well be careful what you wish for for it might come true ;-).

Topic.Title: INTC: Put OCT 20 strike 19 0.02 cents will be 1$ next week

Message.Msg: Assuming you are serious about wanting more info .... Think of owning a put option as like insurance. The HOLDER or BUYER of the put option can make the WRITER or SELLER of the put option take the shares at the strike price. Think of buying a put option as shorting shares but with a maximum loss equal to the optoin purchase price if share prices goes way up. Short term shorting with limited risk. What this guy is saying is to BUY $19 put options that expire next Friday the 20th for 2 cents per share and next week they will be worth $1. Because there is no time value on the options, he is saying that Intel will drop to $18 per share by next Friday. The thread is "bear spam".

Topic.Title: Wednesday

Message.Msg: You can see the impact of the Intel dividend on those options. The call has $1.80 intrinsic value at $20 and the put option is out of the money by $1.80 . The put option is selling for the same $3.50 price. There is a built in dividend drop included in the option pricing. That is why the Intel call options are so cheap and the puts are comparatively expensive. 8-) I AM NOT THE BEST at options either. I like writing them and have the premium leak into my pocket which is why I am more active at puts than calls. When you write them, you can roll them out to avoid execution. If you keep premium on them they will not be exercised early. The only problem is to watch out for exdividend if you are in the money.

Topic.Title: INTC: Put OCT 20 strike 19 0.02 cents will be 1$ next week

Message.Msg: The STRIKE PRICE is the price of the STOCK that you are "insuring". If I BUY a $19 STRIKE PRICE PUT option that expires on OCT 20th, then the sellers are agreeing to buy the INTC shares at the $19 strike price. Someone will sell me the right to make them buy my INTC shares at $19. That is not very valuable when Intel is trading at $21.80. How much would I have to pay to have someone buy my shares at a $20 strike price, on or before Oct 20th. 6 cents $21 strike = 20 cents $22 strike = 60 cents IN THE MONEY $23 strike = $1.34 $24 strike = $2.27 $30 strike = $8.25 Notice that there is near zero premium for deep in the money option strikes. $30 - $8.25 = $21.75

Topic.Title: INTC: Put OCT 20 strike 19 0.02 cents will be 1$ next week

Message.Msg: Yum... Bear Spam

Topic.Title: INTC: Put OCT 20 strike 19 0.02 cents will be 1$ next week

Message.Msg: The $2.18 pricing implies that you are looking at the $20 JAN2013 Call options. The call is IN THE MONEY. I think you are saying it correctly. If you buy one call option contract for $2.18 per share, you will pay $218 plus trade costs and you can then purchase 100 shares of Intel at $20 anytime up to the expiration day. You own the option you bought and can exercise it at your descretion ... any time before expiration. Your reward will be you effectively own the shares by owning the call option and your risk is limited to the $2.18 if Intel goes lower than $20. The CBOE and Option Clearing Corporation have some good online training courses. Look under EDUCATION or COURSES.

Topic.Title: intel's future

Message.Msg: I think folks are missing the point regarding Intel's challenges. Intel's has strong technology and manufacturing. Intel also has cash. But that's not the challenge Intel faces. Inte's challenges are its relevance in the growth market and its bsuiness model. Since the dawn of the PC era, Apple used a different processor (initially Motorola then PowerPC) and a different OS than the common PC (IBM-architecture with Intel X86). More precisely, Intel's X86 won the IBM design partly because it is different than Apple/Motorola. In 2005, Apple adopted Intel X86 architecture in its desktop and notebook computers. Intel (Otellini) was elated! Intel (and Otellini in particular) had pursued Apple for years to get this design win. However, Otellini read the tea-leaves incorrectly. In reality, Jobs recognized that the processor/architecture is no longer the controlling point and therefore, it wouldn't matter if Apple uses the X86 architecure. The control point had moved from hardware/software to data and apps. If you look at Apple's business model today (and Google's, Amazon's, Microsoft's as well), the hardware is merely a conduit to bring business to the data/apps. Once they won your data and apps, they OWN you!! In so doing, the relevance of hardware/processor is on the declined. This trend in turn led to the emergence of ARM, Nividia, Qualcomm, Apple's A4/A5/A6 etc.. Consumers today don't care about what processors they have. What they want is their data and apps! In conclusion, if Intel were to retain its dominance, Intel must find/buy a path to this new reality.

Message.Title: AMD Announces Preliminary Third Quarter Results - BAD
Message.Msg: Revenue Expected to Decrease Approximately 10 Percent Sequentially; Gross Margin Expected to Be Approximately 31 Percent SUNNYVALE, CA--(Marketwire - Oct 11, 2012) - AMD ( NYSE : AMD ) today announced that revenue for the third quarter ended September 29, 2012 is expected to decrease approximately 10 percent sequentially. The company previously forecasted third quarter 2012 revenue to decrease 1 percent, plus or minus 3 percent, sequentially. The lower than anticipated preliminary revenue results are primarily due to weaker than expected demand across all product lines caused by the challenging macroeconomic environment. The company now expects third quarter gross margin to be approximately 31 percent; less than the previous expectation of approximately 44 percent primarily due to an inventory write-down of approximately $100 million due to lower anticipated future demand for certain products. Third quarter gross margin was also negatively impacted by weaker than expected demand, which contributed to lower than anticipated average selling prices (ASPs) for the company's Computing Solutions Group products and lower than expected utilization of its back-end manufacturing facilities. Operating expenses for the third quarter are expected to decline approximately 7 percent sequentially as a result of tightly controlled expenses in the quarter. AMD will report third quarter 2012 results after market close on Thursday, October 18, 2012.

Topic.Title: intel's future

Message.Msg: Intel has been leading the industry in silicon techology and manufacturing since the 1990. I have strong respect for Intel's technology leadership but taht's not the answer. Do the math....if Intel wins all of Qualcomm's mobile business and there is a 1:1 trade of smartphone vs. PC, would Intel be growing or shrinking? What if it is 2:1 trade (i.e., 2 smartphone win for 1 PC loss)? Reality is that the ASP is much lower in the smartphone/Tablet space. Therefore, if smartphone and tablets cannibalize PCs, Intel's revenue will decline even if it wins a signficant amount of mobile business. Before you say "but the margins are good", Intel's massive technology and manufacturing machine needs a huge amount of REVENUE and MARGIN to feed I am TOTALLY for Intel to go agresive in the smartphone/tablet space but I am cautioning it is not a penacea

Message.Title: Do some math on AMD
Message.Msg: AMD forecasts a 10% revenue decline for a company exclusively in the low end PC market. INTC is only about 40% PC. (40% servers, high end, + 20% other). A worst case 4% revenue decline for INTC is 4%*15 $G = $200 Million, much less than their warning, and much less than what analanalysts are predicting..

Message.Title: INTEL a strong buy
Message.Msg: While Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) shares have dipped nearly 11% since the company reduced guidance earlier this month, this has pushed the dividend yield to 4.2% and given investors an even more attractive entry point for this solid core holding. Not only does Intel continue to be one of the most skilled companies at managing its public face, its growth prospects are improving heading into the new year. New 3D Ivy chips under development will compete against QUALCOMM in the mobile space and its server division continues to grow. The company is scheduled to release earnings in mid-October, and I believe buying shares ahead of this announcement will prove solid in both the near and longer-terms.

Message.Title: What better time to buy?
Message.Msg: Think about it...this company is the best chip designer and fabricator in the world. What better time to buy at these cheap levels when everyone is downgrading the stock and panicking over the PC being dead. Intel is a fast mover and its agility in design/fab is tested and established again and again. Once its 3D Ivy chips rule...if you are a device mfg and don't have one of these chips in it...guess what you will be left behind. Looking ahead into 2013 this stock will form a base soon and start to climb once it releases news on its latest mobile chips. In addition, while you wait you get paid a 4+ dividend. Thank you ANALysts for the cheap price.

Topic.Title: intel's future

Message.Msg: You really don't understand what's going on, do you? This isn't like the RISC/x86 wars of the late 1980s / early 1990s. The big phone and tablet guys aren't interested in buying discrete CPU chips that virtually define their product for them. Like I said, they want to define the dies and the packaged chip for themselves. They also see no win in going down the PC commoditization path, where Intel defines all of the important hardware value and Microsoft (or now Google) takes the software value. So in your view its Intel / Android, and Apple, Samsung and everyone else just become packaging and logistics companies like the PC guys did? I doubt it. The world is different. When the PC was king there wasn't the IP or the tools or the integration technologies available like there are now. And at mobile volumes the cost of a mask set divides away quickly. ARM isn't the big winner beating Intel, it's the system-level guys adding the real value, and CPUs aren't much of a differentiator.
